section.title: Overview
section.para: In any computing environment, managing dependencies is difficult. The eXist-db package repository makes it easy to manage and deploy external packages (.xar archives) which include everything they need to run third party XQuery libraries to full applications or other XML technology functionality.
eXist-db is integrated with an expath repository which can contain .xar packages containing jars, xquery libraries, xslt and other XML Technology packages.

Deploying an XQuery package, such as the popular Functx XQuery library, into the repository can be reduced to a single click to install . If everything went ok the functx-1.0.xar package should now be installed (you need to restart eXist) and the following XQuery should run properly in the XQuery sandbox.
Functx XQuery library example
import module namespace functx="http://www.functx.com";
functx:capitalize-first('hello')
list installed packages

important.para: Any newly installed packages still requires you to restart eXistdb, a limitation we will be addressing in the near future.

section.title: Installation
section.para:
This module relies on the presence of the following jar files in the EXIST_HOME/lib/core folder. This jar is included in the lib/core already.
pkg-repo.jar

If you are working off development /trunk you will need to do the following as eXist-db now depends on package management repository.
svn update to pick up new code
ensure include.module.expathrepo = true in your extensions/local.build.properties
rebuild eXist (so repo extension module gets built)
You will then need to add the following module elements to your conf.xml
<module class="org.exist.xquery.modules.expathrepo.ExpathPackageModule" uri="http://exist-db.org/xquery/repo" />
<module class="org.exist.xquery.modules.compression.CompressionModule" uri="http://exist-db.org/xquery/compression" />
The repo module extension should be enabled by default but you must ensure that the compression module is installed.

section.title: Administration
section.para: You can control which modules are loaded into eXist using the repo manager admin.
From the repo admin ui you can upload packages from your computer or from public package repositories.

important.para: You need to ensure compression module is enabled via conf.xml for repo admin ui to work properly.

section.title: .xar Archive
section.para: The repository supports package archive in .xar format, containing XQuery, XSLT, Schema and XProc modules

A .xar package format is a set of files bundled with a package description (expath-pkg.xml). For example, The FunctX XQuery library is packaged up as follows
functx-1.0.xar package distribution
expath-pkg.xml functx/ functx.xql functx.xsl
The expath-pkg.xml contains package description. The .xar comprises of the zipped up distribution.

We have shipped a few .xar packages in the .xar directory which get built automatically by eXist. You can use to test installing a package. This is achieved by using controller.xql to identify
Functx-1.0 install | remove
XQuery-Json-0.1 install | remove

A more advanced package could contain other archive resources. We can package up eXist own modules into jars and distribute them using .xar. The following expath-pkg.xml package describes eXist's own math module.
package description for extensions math module
<package xmlns="http://expath.org/ns/pkg"> <module name="math" version="1.0"> <title>Math extension packaged as xar</title> <exist> <jar>math.jar</jar> <java> <namespace>http://exist-db.org/xquery/math</namespace> <class>org.exist.xquery.modules.math.MathModule</class> </java> </exist> </module> </package>

The math jar that is referenced from expath-pkg.xml needs to contain the correct MANIFEST.MF which lists out any other dependent jars (exist.jar and xmldb.jar), as shown below.
math.jar MANIFEST.MF
Manifest-Version: 1.0 Ant-Version: Apache Ant 1.7.1 Created-By: 14.1-b02-90 (Apple Inc.) Project-Name: eXist Project-Version: 1.5.0dev Class-Path: exist.jar xmldb.jar

Then its just a matter of including all the extensions classes.
xar-math target in extensions/modules/build.xml creates math.jar which ships inside math-1.0.xar
drwxr-xr-x 0 31-Jul-2010 22:09:40 META-INF/ -rw-r--r-- 183 31-Jul-2010 22:09:38 META-INF/MANIFEST.MF drwxr-xr-x 0 31-Jul-2010 14:03:36 org/ drwxr-xr-x 0 31-Jul-2010 14:03:36 org/exist/ drwxr-xr-x 0 31-Jul-2010 14:03:36 org/exist/xquery/ drwxr-xr-x 0 31-Jul-2010 14:03:46 org/exist/xquery/modules/ drwxr-xr-x 0 31-Jul-2010 14:03:46 org/exist/xquery/modules/math/ -rw-r--r-- 1867 31-Jul-2010 14:03:46 org/exist/xquery/modules/math/MathModule.class -rw-r--r-- 3695 31-Jul-2010 14:03:46 org/exist/xquery/modules/math/NoParamFunctions.class -rw-r--r-- 6996 31-Jul-2010 14:03:46 org/exist/xquery/modules/math/OneParamFunctions.class -rw-r--r-- 4522 31-Jul-2010 14:03:46 org/exist/xquery/modules/math/TwoParamFunctions.class

We will probably be repackaging all existing extensions to take advantage of this, for now you can test deploying eXists own extensions using the Math-1.0.xar which is eXist's own math module repackaged up using .xar.
Math-1.0 install | remove
Once you have installed and restarted eXist you should now be able to use math functions.
List existing packages
import module namespace math="http://exist-db.org/xquery/math";
math:pi()
click here to test math function

section.title: Library and Application packages
section.para:
There are two kinds of packages:
Library packages: when you want to distribute and deploy code libraries to eXist XML Database repository
Applicaiton packages: when you want to distribute and deploy applications into database itself

Each package type, will contain both an expath-pkg.xml and repo.xml metadata file. The expath-pkg.xml file contains the information for relating URI namespaces with a specific library. The repo.xml file is an eXistdb specific metadata file which defines if the package is a library or an application.
myapp repo.xml
<meta xmlns="http://exist-db.org/xquery/repo"> <author>James Fuller</author> <website>http://www.webcomposite.com</website> <license>GNU-LGPL</license> <copyright>true</copyright> <description>Example illustrating how to package up applications.</description> <type>application</type> <status>experimental</status> </meta>
The myapp-0.1.xar contains an example application which when installed in the repo admin area and activated will offer the ability to also deploy the application.
List contents of myapp Application package
drwxr-xr-x 0 24-Aug-2010 13:44:36 myapp/ drwxr-xr-x 0 24-Aug-2010 11:56:38 myapp/data/ drwxr-xr-x 0 23-Aug-2010 19:14:30 myapp/lib/ -rw-r--r-- 288 23-Aug-2010 19:14:22 expath-pkg.xml -rw-r--r-- 115 24-Aug-2010 13:16:50 myapp/data/contact.xml -rw-r--r-- 94 24-Aug-2010 13:37:04 myapp/index.html -rw-r--r-- 147 24-Aug-2010 12:50:44 myapp/lib/util.xqm -rw-r--r-- 17351 24-Aug-2010 13:33:14 myapp/logo.jpg -rw-r--r-- 250 24-Aug-2010 13:43:30 myapp/test.xqy -rw-r--r-- 336 24-Aug-2010 12:14:30 repo.xml
Deployment will copy the 'myapp' directory, inside the .xar, to a collection of the same name inside of the database.

section.title: Interacting with Repository from XQuery
section.para: The repository includes an extension module which provides three functions for programmatically controlling repository from XQuery

section.title: repo:list()
section.para:
The repo:list() function returns a sequence of strings containing the names of installed packages.
packages/list-repo.xqy: List existing packages
import module namespace repo="http://exist-db.org/xquery/repo";
repo:list()
click here to list packages in repository

section.title: repo:install( URI )
section.para:
The repo:install() function returns a boolean value indicating success or failure of installation.
packages/install-functx.xqy: Install existing packages
import module namespace repo="http://exist-db.org/xquery/repo";
repo:install('http://127.0.0.1:8080/exist/repo/packages/functx-1.0.xar')
click here to install functx

section.title: repo:remove( package name )
section.para:
The repo:remove() function returns a sequence of strings containing the names of installed packages.
packages/remove-functx.xqy: Remove existing packages
import module namespace repo="http://exist-db.org/xquery/repo";
repo:remove('functx-1.0')
click here to remove functx

important.para: These functions will soon be usable only by DBA user, as we are still developing they will be available by guest user for short period of time.

section.title: Public Repository
section.para: Each eXist XML Database ships with its own Public repository, a facility for which packages can be distributed to other eXistdb instances. Public repositories are used by the eXistdb repo administration module.
The Public repository is by default empty and can be reached here

important.para: To upload packages into this public repository you must amend permissions on /db/repo collection.

ul.li: Expath Package Specification: Community defined specification
Expath Packaging Documentation: Information on vendor specific expath repository implementations.

section.title: Why do we need package management ?
section.para: Dependency management is difficult, but its also important to gaurd against 'bloat'. Over the coming weeks/months we will be exporting functionality into third party .xar packages and it will reduce eXist core as well make it easy for you to create and distribute your own libraries and applications.

section.title: Where is the package repository located ?
section.para: The repository gets created under the webapp/WEB-INF/expathrepo directory, alternatively it will use the directory stored in java.io.tmp directory to install the repository.

section.title: Can I interact with the repository from the commandline ?
section.para: Yes, currently you can run the expath package jar commandline utility againt the eXist package repository. In the future we may extend the expath package specification to suit eXist needs which may make it incompatible. In addition you can use eXist Apache Ant xdb:query Task to install and remove packages.

section.title: Can we use package types other then XQuery modules ?
section.para: Currently we are focused on making XQuery module packages, though in the near future we should be able to deploy full applications with xproc, schema, data, resources, as well as java jars.

section.title: I want to make my own .xar package
section.para: Its very easy to package up your own XQuery modules to create a .xar format. Essentially you need to define expath-pkg.xml file which describes the package, then include the libraries then zip it up and give it a .xar extension. You can unzip the webapp/repo/packages/functx-1.0.xar package as an example or review the expath specification.

section.title: I want more developer information
section.para: You can find more information in the sourcecode README at extensions/modules/src/org.exist.modules/expathrepo/readme.txt.
